Then the limit of 1/x as x approaches 0 from the right would be infinity, approaching from below.
But do not forget that it’s most formal to say that the limit doesn’t exist in that case, since infinity is not an element of the set of real numbers. Furthermore, “negative infinity” would imply that infinity really is a number so that it can have an additive inverse.

Your definition of a group is different from how I've usually seen it presented, and this raises questions.

You define a group as a collection of symmetric actions on some mathematical object.

Other sources define a group as the set of mathematical objects that can be transformed into each other by applying some combination of allowed actions. These sources present symmetry as an important part of group theory because it relates to how certain actions transform an object back into itself, but they don't present it as part of what makes a group a group.

My own definition of group theory, for comical effect when someone at a party asks you to define it in 30 seconds:

"If you have a thing, and you have a bunch of things you can do to the thing, and when you do the things to the thing you turn the thing into other things, then all those things are a group. But sometimes, when you do a thing to the thing, instead of turning the thing into another thing you turn the thing into the same thing, and then you have symmetry."
